newsitem.title: FRANCE: Oil consumers urge "realism" in climate talks.
newsitem.headline: Oil consumers urge "realism" in climate talks.

text.p: Energy ministers from the world's leading industrial powers appealed on Friday for realism in setting targets for the reduction of noxious emissions believed to cause global warming.
International Energy Agency (IEA) ministers also committed themselves to finding concrete strategies for cutting pollution in the run-up to a climate change summit in Japan this year.

The Paris-based IEA, part of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD), called on larger developing nations to play their part in the fight to restrain output of heat-trapping greenhouse gases.
"We have to make a difficult trade-off between ambition and realism," IEA chairman and Dutch Economic Affairs Minister Hans Wijers told a news conference.
IEA countries must devise and implement energy policies that were "realistic, achievable and cost-effective," said an IEA statement released after a half day of ministerial talks.
"We have to think about the large developing countries," said Wijers. "They have to be involved somewhere."
About 150 nations are trying to negotiate legally binding cuts in greenhouse gases in a deal to be signed in Kyoto, Japan, in December.
The initiative follows up the 1992 Rio de Janeiro Earth Summit that committed developed countries to reducing carbon dioxide emissions to 1990 levels by the year 2000.
Most of the IEA's 24 member countries will fail to meet their Rio targets.
"I believe we must come out of Kyoto with goals that are realistic and achievable and in which the world can have some confidence," U.S. Energy Secretary Federico Pena said.
So far only European Union nations have shown their hand, proposing a 15 percent cut in emissions from 1990 levels by the year 2010.
The United States, easily the world's largest energy consumer, has committed itself to seeking binding targets but has not yet said what the new goals beyond 2000 should be.
Pena said he had "some concerns" about the EU proposal, for which he had not seen the analysis. The United States would make its own proposals in "several weeks or months", he said.

The IEA gave cautious backing to a U.S. idea for emissions trading -- allowing countries to barter emissions credits or implement projects that reduce emissions in developing nations -- saying it should be given careful consideration.
The U.S. backs emissions trading as a way of getting the private sector involved but environmentalists have condemned the scheme as a cop-out.

"It will be very complicated to make emissions trading measurable and open to account," IEA executive director Robert Priddle said. "There is a long way to go yet to see whether it is a practical option."
Ministers renewed their call for maintenance of sufficient strategic oil reserves to protect against the possibility of a shortage on international markets.

"Oil security remains a concern, particularly given the prospect of increasing import dependence...and the increasing concentration of remaining oil reserves in the Middle East," they said in a statement.
The IEA was set up in 1974 originally to defend consumers against huge oil price rises, but has since developed into a specialist thinktank under the auspices of the OECD.
